Instrument.name: Laser Rangefinder for CLEM1
Instrument.description:
The Laser Rangefinder (LIDAR) instrument utilized on the Clementine mission employed a telescope shared with a HiRes camera to measure the lunar surface's slant range using a 1064 nm NdYag laser signal. It featured an avalanche photodiode (APD) detector with temperature compensation, programmable thresholding, and a transimpedance amplifier for signal processing. The LIDAR gathered high-resolution topographical data from altitudes below 640 km, enabling the mapping of lunar topography and gravity variations, which helped characterize the Moon's interior structure.
During its operation, LIDAR had a 20% success rate in range measurements, particularly successful over smoother mare surfaces compared to rougher highlands. The instrument operated primarily in 'ON' and 'OFF' modes and was able to range at 8Hz just before leaving the Moon. Data collected included time-tagged clock cycles that were used to determine surface positions and heights, resulting in a comprehensive topographic model of the Moon. The operational rates and parameters were influenced by various factors like orbital height and surface albedo, and daily threshold values were manually adjusted based on mission experience.
